description: {"blocks":[{"key":"3bkf1","text":"Restriction-site Associated DNA sequencing (RADseq) offers a simple, affordable, and versatile approach to swiftly genotype thousands of genetic markers without prior optimization for population genetic and phylogenetic analyses on any kind of organism (Baird et al. 2008). Although RADseq protocols have undergone significant advancements, they remain difficult to implement de novo for researchers inexperienced with the technique in labs that are not a priori equipped for NGS technologies. ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c0gca","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4hgd4","text":"The protocol presented here aims to facilitate such implementation. It consists of an adaptation of the double digest RADseq (ddRADseq) protocol proposed by Peterson et al. (2012) and further modified by Brelsford et al. (2016).  Compared to the latter, it optimizes reagent usages and introduces a facilitated procedure of AMPure purification of an entire 96-well plate at once, by using a custom magnetic 96-pin device.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1sun","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fls3","text":"The procedure goes as follows. Genomic DNA of the samples undergoes enzyme restriction by SbfI, a 'rare'-cutter, and MseI, a more 'frequent'-cutter. The digested DNA fragments are then ligated to adapters on each end, with the SbfI adapter containing individual 4-8 bp barcodes for multiplexing samples in the library. The ligated fragments are then purified and amplified by replicate PCRs using primers that include TruSeq Illumina indices for sequencing as well as indexing. PCR products are then pooled and size selection (400-500bp) is performed either with a PippinPrep Instrument or through ad hoc migration/excision on an agarose gel. The size-selected library is purified, quantified, and controlled before Illumina sequencing.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"729n7","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dk5qk","text":"So far, this protocol, or the previous version it derives from (Brelsford et al., 2016), has been successfully used in phylogeographic studies across various non-model animals, including amphibians, reptiles, mammals, and insects (e.g. Ambu et al., 2023).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dnh88","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"caq56","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c3kln","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":74,"offset":60}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"sh3f","text":"All steps can be visualized by a detailed video tutorial on How to double digest Restriction site Associated DNA sequencing (ddRADseq). ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"1A6C2ED461854DFEA7047FADF4ADCDB9","url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y4u1t0cTQVc"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"4v47v","text":"Prevent cross-contamination by using low-retention filter tips for all pipetting procedures. If possible, we recommend working under a laminar flow bench to protect the samples and further avoid contamination. A non-template control on the plate may also be incorporated to stay tuned for possible contamination. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pv3d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1576b","text":"Handle the SbfI barcoded adapter plate with great care, as cross-contamination on this plate might invalidate your entire study and any future study using that plate. Moreover, barcode cross-contamination may only become apparent through inconsistent results after data analysis.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: So far, this protocol, or the previous version it derives from (Brelsford et al., 2016), has been successfully used in phylogeographic studies across various non-model animals, including amphibians, reptiles, mammals, and insects (e.g. Ambu et al., 2023).

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6m1tl","text":"Before starting the protocol, it is necessary to prepare the SbfI and MseI adapters as follows:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bqfqj","text":"In this section of the protocol, the restriction digestion reaction of samples will be carried out.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5vvv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8t6n6","text":"Purify the ligation reaction product using an AMPure XP protocol with a 1:1 ratio and elute in 45 uL of nuclease-free water.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhduo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ss5d","text":"We introduced the use of a custom-made magnetic 96-pin plate (see YouTube Tutorial, starting at 11:40) to increase the efficiency of the protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f6cjm","text":"The library amplification/PCR step employs Illumina PCR primers to amplify restricted fragments from their ligated adapters.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avp9h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7j3ej","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"93vhn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f3lkq","text":"To ameliorate stochastic differences in PCR production of fragments and obtain larger DNA quantity for the size-selection stage, we run two separate 10 µL reactions per restriction-ligation product, which are later pooled together.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fpakr","text":"In this section of the protocol, the prepared double-stranded SbfI and MseI adapters (as described in step 1 - Preparation) will be ligated to the restriction-digested DNA (see step 2 - Restriction Reaction).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"edb6a","text":"Proceed to Illumina sequencing or equivalent. DNA quantity and mean fragment length can be used to calculate the molarity of the library.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33kt7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3ktjb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5gq1i","text":"The sequencing strategy depends on the need of your study, but also on the genome size of your study organism. The bigger the genome, the higher number of reads will be needed to obtain a proper coverage for enough loci across samples included in the library. We have typically used one lane of NextSeq 550 (which yields ~400M reads) for 96-sample libraries in species of 5-10 Gb genomes. The bigger the genomes, the higher the number of reads needed, or the fewer samples to be included in the sequenced library.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"8id1","text":"Quantify the amount of DNA using a fluorimeter (e.g., Qubit).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"246i7","text":"Check size selection and library fragment size using gel electrophoresis or a TapeStation/Bioanalyzer/Fragment Analyzer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"n3cn","text":"Conduct size selection within the range of 400 to 500 base pairs. You can achieve this using a PippinPrep instrument, following the provided guidelines from the manufacturer. Another method involves a prolonged migration on an agarose gel, excising the desired region, and purifying it using a gel extraction kit, as outlined below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9od43","text":"Check for proper migration by very quick UV exposure and prepare tubes for the gel pieces.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cch0q","text":"Cut the 400 - 500 bp region on a UV table using sterile scalpel/razor blades. Minimize UV exposure by only cutting a few gel pieces at a time and individualize each piece in the prepared tubes. Try to remove the empty agarose to limit the amount of gel to be purified and be careful not to include ladder fragments in your excisions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69ap4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8lvmi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c6n5v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6f8dv","text":"Protect yourself from UV light by wearing appropriate protective clothing and UV protection glasses.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"j8te","text":"Purify each gel slice separately using a gel extraction kit (e.g., Monarch DNA Gel Extraction Kit from New England Biolabs). Elute in ~15 - 20 µL of elution buffer and pool elution products into a single tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"56i97","text":"Accurately measure the total elution volume (in µL, with a pipet) and its concentration (in ng/µL, with a fluorometer, e.g., Qubit, using 1 µL of sample). Multiply both numbers to obtain the amount of DNA in your library (in ng). You can then divide this number by 25 to calculate the elution volume needed to concentrate the library to an optimal 25 ng/µL in the next step. Keep in mind that you might lose 10 - 15 % of your DNA yield during this concentration step and that it is best to have at least 10 µL of library (down to 3-4 ng/µL is still ok).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e3s96","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"kd6k","text":"Safety Warning for Wearing Protective Gear (Goggles) When Working with UV Light:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":80}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gb6m","text":"Caution: when working with UV light, it is imperative to prioritize your safety. Always wear appropriate protective gear, including safety goggles, to shield your eyes from potentially harmful UV radiation. Unprotected exposure to UV light can lead to serious eye damage. Protect your vision – safeguard your eyes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pnlc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4hku","text":"Safety Warning for Handling Ethidium Bromide (if you are still working with EtBr):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":82}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3u7p","text":"Caution: ethidium bromide is a hazardous chemical commonly used in molecular biology. It is known to be a potential mutagen and should be handled with extreme care. To minimize risks to your health and the environment, follow these guidelines:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e34","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bolt","text":"Personal Protective Equipment: wear appropriate personal protective equipment, including lab coats, gloves, and safety goggles, when working with ethidium bromide.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5641i","text":"Adequate Ventilation: conduct all procedures involving ethidium bromide in a properly ventilated area or under a hood to minimize exposure to fumes.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"erefu","text":"Avoid Skin Contact: minimize skin contact with ethidium bromide. If skin contact occurs, wash the affected area immediately with copious amounts of water.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dl1f","text":"Use Safer Alternatives: whenever possible, consider replacing ethidium bromide with safer alternatives, such as Midori Green, which is non-hazardous and less harmful to human health and the environment.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6k7a0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
